replies.author: @StrayChoom
replies.text:
‚Å†@senerzenehhh not so much. They weren‚Äôt Communists of the Marxist variety. 
They had some socialist ideals of the utopian variant.
Not scientific socialism, like Marxist socialism, but there were & are still major, major differences.

They were still definitively a capitalist party, with some increased involvement of state over the current neoliberal paradigm in the west.

That‚Äôs not communist at all.

That is very, very different from current ideas of communism or socialism, and even were viewed differently at the time.

Communism (lower phase, now called socialism) being:
Where private property (property of speculative investment, stocks, fiscal assets, etc‚Ä¶) are abolished & the means of production (machines, tools, etc‚Ä¶) are owned & controlled by the workers, & necessities are decommodified.
[Or in many interpretations means of production owned by the state, which the workers also control more directly than in a capitalist nation ~ but anarchists and communists still debate the best approach]

EDIT: upper phase communism, usually just called communism, being a stateless, classless, moneyless society.

Though moneyless might be a misnomer. Money is permitted as means of consumption, but you cannot purchase capital with it.

Capital being the means of production. 
So people say ‚Äúuse labour vouchers‚Äù but this is in principle basically just money in most cases. This can be done by simply banning purchasing of capital and private property.

Private property distinct from personal property. Private property is like basically when you own a stock, & its price is susceptible to market forces so it can operate as a vehicle for investment. 

You can own a house, but the houses price won‚Äôt change, or in general housing might just be free with some degree of ownership involved.

Basically the idea is capitalists exploit the system like a video game. They get exponential & compounding returns, workers only get linear. 

On top of the existing tension between workers and capitalists (their bosses, the company owner(s), etc‚Ä¶)

Socialism wishes to patch this exploit out of the game. Communism wishes to do away with class conflict entirely.

So TLDR: yeah no neither upper or lower phase apply to Weimar socdems.

replies.author: @coreyander286
replies.text:
The grandchildren's fear of having to flee back to Germany being extremely overblown is progress, I guess. The Civil Rights Act had passed, that wasn't with us in 1945. We have legal gay marriage, and it's much easier to be trans than it was in 1945, that's progress. Socialism is more popular today than it was in 1945, or McCarthyist 1950s, or the 2000s even. That's progress. People are no longer justifying the Vietnam or Iraq Wars, that's progress. Girls are graduating from university much more than they did in your grandparent's time, that's progress. People are generally a lot less racist, and a lot less antisemitic than they were in America in 1945. America elected Joe Biden rather than Trump in 2020, that's an improvement over 2016 at least. In 1945 there was virtually no awareness of global warming, today pretty much everyone has accepted it and the only anti-environmentalist argument we're hearing anymore is "well China and India are doing most of it", extremely little outright denial of the very fact of its existence as you'd hear in the '00s. Life expectancy has gone up.

So, there's been a lot of progress. They fact that red America has been deranged into QAnon territory by social media and Republicans were able to turn the Supreme Court right be more or less pure patience doesn't negate that progress.

replies.author: @DevinMacGregor
replies.text:
@j0j0dartiste21 That was something pushed for in the later 80s after Robertson lost the GOP Primary. He started a grassroots campaign that would win states from the ground up. The ultimate goal was to win enough states to call a national constitutional convention to where they could rewrite the Constitution. So essentially when the red states have enough state power they could then dictate what the constitution says and the other blue states would have to follow as they would have no choice. The red states would have the majority needed to do this.

Some only think the Constitution can be changed by Congress voting on Amendments and then each state ratifying it.

replies.author: @DevinMacGregor
replies.text:
@bethmoore7722 When African Americans were migrating to CA for jobs they moved into 6 districts which had been staunchly GOP.  People often think of CA having been this always a blue state. When looking at the map they moved into roughly the middle of these six. So they redistricted with drawing a box around them to make one district thus making 6 into 7 districts. The original 6 could remain strongly GOP favored.

CA now has the the California Citizens Redistricting Commission which is ab independent commission.  The bulk of people moving out of state are lower income, i.e. 50K and a large amount of GOP voters with the majority coming in 100K earners and lean Left or at least democrat.

replies.author: @cryptofacts4u
replies.text:
I'm from Austin Texas and I live in the city. They basically cut Austin into a four-piece pie where most of the pie stretches out into the rural areas.... So when I vote I'm voting with people a hundred miles away in towns I've never been to.... Meanwhile the person 10 minutes east of me is voting in a completely different district, the people 10 minutes north of me are voting in a completely different district and the people 20 minutes south of me are voting in a completely different district, and these districts all stretch out way into the rural areas and the places that none of us go.... But all those places vote red so it's almost like they don't care represent the people or to create voting districts that match the realities on the ground, they've used the power of Big Data since 2010 to rewrite the districts to make it so that even when they get less votes the Republican Party wins seats

I don't know if you know this but almost every year the Republicans get less votes than the Democrats but they get more seats per vote and it's all thanks to one Republican who realized that if they pushed really hard in all the governor races, and were able to control majority of them by 2010 they'd be in control of redistricting for the next decade and a paired that with big data that didn't exist 10 20 years before and they were successful and we have been dealing with the repercussions ever since

replies.author: @cryptofacts4u
replies.text:
What's really scary is now there are a growing number of Republicans who are putting forward the legal Theory that state courts can't rule on elections, it's called The Independent legislature Theory. It basically would mean that A republican-controlled legislature could reject the electors of the people and choose their own electors for the candidate that lost in their state, and the courts wouldn't be able to do anything to stop it. 

There's a case that's coming up before The supreme court, they have chosen to hear the arguments, I forget the name of the case but it directly deals with the independent legislature Theory and if they rule in its favor we could be in a very scary place soon

replies.author: @genericyoutubeaccount579
replies.text: @cryptofacts4u The term Gerrymander goes back to 1812. Gerrymandering is a fundamental part of American democracy going back 200 years. This is nothing new.

replies.author: @cryptofacts4u
replies.text:
@genericyoutubeaccount579 you know you're correct that gerrymandering has a very long history, stretching back to the times when the president could be shot and that breaking news takes weeks to get everyone across the country. Like how news of the civil War ending took 3 weeks to reach a particular town in Texas which is where we get the Juneteenth celebration from.

But now we're living in the digital age. Now we're living in an age where the politicians drawing up these maps can look at massive amounts of data. And you can use that massive amount of data to create hyper targeted districts that you couldn't feasibly create so accurately even 20 years ago.

replies.author: @jannegrey
replies.text:
@connorhutchinson9615 Depending how you define it, you can say we already have it. Though obviously if we go with the spirit of this video and slightly less loose definitions of "fascist" - then yeah. Current one isn't fascist yet. But they do have this tendencies. They control state media and their level of being "fair" to government is closer to Russian or North Korean State media than to Western ones.

But there was still possibility that they could be voted out in elections next year. However due to the War in Ukraine, people will get behind that government. Especially since they decided to increase Military spending etc. The problem is that even I agree with them on those 2 things. We need to support Ukraine as much as possible and we need better army. However on that second point they are only doing flashy stuff. They don't spend money wisely. They throw it away for increase of capabilities in 1 specialty for 10 or more times the cost it would take if it was done smartly. Their plans to have 300.000 strong Military are.... weird. We have problems with maintaining numbers in current army - and now we would have to expand it by more than 100%? Ridiculous.

But that makes them popular. Problem is that people either love them or hate them. Same with other parties. And the left in Poland as usual is divided and from time to time they also suggest some ridiculous things. Center is almost non-existent at this point. You have parties that are center-right and center-left in theory, but in reality those are only less fringe options. PO (previous government, before 2015) had a lot of issues, but they were right-wing light and even had some centrists.

And current government tried taking over the power, when they ruled in 2005-2007, but were ousted in elections, because people turned out to vote in droves against them. But back then they didn't manage to take over media completely. And they didn't hijack judiciary. They've learned their lesson sadly.

@H4FF Abortion is very complicated issue. It's crazy to portray it like if anyone having problem with abortion is against women's right.

replies.author: @jemolk8945
replies.text:
@AABB-zb6dv Frankly, it's not very complicated at all.  The cases that all the fearmongering is about with regard to late-term abortions "just because" don't actually happen, and the strict regulations only really have the effect, in the real world, of destroying lives.  Even if you don't like it happening, trying to interfere with such healthcare decisions will kill some people and torture others.  There are plenty of ways to lower abortion rates and generally improve outcomes that _don't_ cause tremendous suffering, like comprehensive sex ed and easy access to contraception, as well as access to abortion on demand (yes, really), good prenatal care, ensuring that no one's impoverished enough that they won't be able to take care of a child, etc., etc.  But the anti-abortion crowd doesn't want to go with any of those; the movement as a whole, at least, would rather just ban it, because it really is about being against women's rights.

I don't doubt that there are some true believers around, but they're wrong on the facts and following the word of malevolent liars who care chiefly about controlling others and could hardly care less about life.

replies.author: @thoughtproduction1406
replies.text:
@SupremeEmperorKizza "[T]he USA is not a democracy but a constitutional republic". Do you know what any of democracy, constitutional, or republic means? Because this phrase is oft repeated as if it makes the slightest bit of sense, when it doesn't. Those terms are not mutually exclusive.

Constitutional means that your nation is governed by a constitution. France and North Korea both have a constitution. One is a democracy, the other an authoritarian state. 

Republic means that power is held by - and this is important - elected officials. What matters now is who elects those officials. Venice was a republic, but not a democracy because the doge was elected by wealthy merchants. So what makes a democracy? 

The right of all citizens of a state to elect amongst themselves their representatives. The US is a democracy because it upholds that right. You (the citizen) vote in elections.

In other words, the US is a constitutional republic AND a democracy. 

What you - and most conservatives - appear to be confused by is direct versus representative democracy. The closest thing to a direct democracy in existence today is Switzerland. It asks the people what they want (through referendums/referenda) and then follows through based on their decisions. This is not how the US (or nearly any other democracy) is governed

replies.author: @-tera-3345
@markevans8206
replies.text:
‚Äã@tylerbozinovski427 Republics are and always have been, a form of democracy. No matter what you think the founders intended, they were very clear in their rhetoric that from day one, the goal was for "some" people to vote and for the elected officials to represent "them." The 15th and 19th Amendments of the Constitution clearly expand the right to vote to citizens over 18 with some potential exemptions.

So the claim that "The US is not a democracy, it's a constitutional republic" is what I call "a pointless point." The US has been slowly dragging itself in the direction of those aspirational words of Abraham Lincoln, "Of the People, By the People, For the People." In my experience, people who love to make the claim that the US is not a democracy are really saying, "There is a large portion of the US citizenry that I think don't deserve representation even though they are taxed and subject to US laws."

The "mob rules" excuse wears mighty thin when one party openly tries to lock in its primacy by demonizing actual minority populations.

author: @TheDarthbinky
text: As an American who got a degree in German and political science (yeah, it's a very useful degree...), I constantly find myself trying to explain that the rise of Fascism (including Nazism) wasn't just like one day this wizard shows up and magically turns the country into a dictatorship. It was a lengthy process that took nearly a decade and a half in Germany. Yes, Italy's transformation was faster but they had their own issues, and ultimately still had a monarch who wielded power above Mussolini (and Mussolini was ultimately brought down when the King fired him). Even once Hitler was in power and the Enabling Act was passed, it still took about a year and a half for the Gleichschaltung to complete. That doesn't mean we shouldn't be vigilant; quite the opposite, we should be aware of the gradual slip to authoritarianism at the hands of populist right-wing demagoguery.

After the election of Duke Albert V as German King Albert II, Vienna became the capital of the Holy Roman Empire. Albert's name is remembered for his expulsion of the Jewish population of Vienna in 1421/22. Eventually, in 1469, Vienna was given its own bishop, and the Stephansdom became a cathedral.

The next 30 years saw the end of the Habsburg dynasty‚Äôs claim to European hegemony in any real sense. The aggressions of¬†Louis XIV¬†of France, from 1667 onward, took territory after territory from the Spanish Habsburgs‚Äîlarge parts of Flanders, the rest of Artois, and other areas in the Netherlands, as well as the whole Franche Comt√© and, in 1684, the stronghold of Luxembourg‚Äîand demonstrated at the same time that the imperial Habsburgs, preoccupied as they were with the Turkish assault from Hungary, could not effectively defend the German frontier west of the Rhine. After being saved from the crisis of the Turkish siege of Vienna in 1683, the imperial Habsburgs did indeed obtain one dynastically significant success‚Äîthe conversion, in 1687, of the Hungarian crown into an hereditary one for themselves‚Äîbut by that time it was plain to Europe that the most¬†formidable¬†dynasty was no longer the Habsburg but the¬†Bourbon. In the¬†War of the Grand Alliance¬†(1689‚Äì97) the rising powers that 100 years earlier had been Habsburg Spain‚Äôs principal enemies and feeble France‚Äôs most fluent encouragers, the Dutch and English, led those supporting the Habsburgs against Louis XIV. 

Apart from the Bourbon ascendancy, there was a further reason for other powers to watch with jealous solicitude over the fate of Spain. The physical debility of¬†Charles II¬†of Spain was such that no male heir could be expected to be born to him, and the question of his succession was one of great concern to the European powers. Up to 1699 it was understood that his crowns would pass to the electoral prince of Bavaria, Joseph Ferdinand, son of his niece Maria Antonia, daughter of the emperor¬†Leopold I. That arrangement was generally acceptable because, by transferring the Spanish inheritance to the Bavarian house of Wittelsbach, it would not necessarily upset the¬†balance of power¬†between the imperial Habsburgs and Bourbon France. In 1699, however, when Joseph Ferdinand died, the¬†moribund¬†Charles II‚Äôs next natural heirs were the descendants (1) of his half-sister, who had married Louis XIV of France, and (2) of his father‚Äôs two sisters, of whom one had been Louis XIV‚Äôs mother and the other the emperor Leopold I‚Äôs. Critical tension developed: on the one hand neither the imperial Habsburgs nor their British and Dutch friends could consent to their Bourbon enemy‚Äôs acquiring the whole Spanish inheritance; on the other neither Bourbon France nor its British and Dutch enemies wanted to see an imperial Habsburg reunite in one pair of hands most of what the emperor Charles V had had in 1519. Charles II in the meantime regarded any partition of his inheritance as a humiliation to Spain: dying in 1700, he named as his sole heir a Bourbon prince,¬†Philip¬†of Anjou, the second of Louis XIV‚Äôs grandsons. The¬†War of the Spanish Succession¬†ensued.

‚Äã@ForelliBoy Sort of, yeah. In the end, Hitler and Mussolini seized power that way. Both were populist demagogues who cut deals with wealthy elites because those wealthy elites were more afraid of socialists than fascists. But they needed popular support to get there; Mussolini was able to channel popular rage at the results of WW1 into his quick rise to power, and Hitler had to take a more gradual approach. Once each reached a certain level of popularity (for example, Hitler and the Nazis had about 33% of the seats in parliament; Mussolini, to oversimplify, gathered a small army and "persuaded" the King to make him prime minister), they then cut deals with the elites to come to power. But Franco seized power in Spain through winning a civil war, as did Dollfuss in Austria (to oversimplify a little). Other fascist movements like the Ustase took power when Germany occupied their country and elevated them to power. Not all fascists come to power the same way, I guess is my point.

And here's the thing that doesn't get talked about a lot... western capitalist countries like the US and UK weren't particularly troubled by the rise of fascism (and even had fascist movements of their own, such as the Silver Shirts and the BUF respectively... none were particularly popular but they existed). Italy, France, and the UK were on rather good terms until 1935 and the Italian invasion of Ethiopia. They even tried to form a military alliance (the Stresa Front) with the aim of attacking Germany for the attempted Nazi coup in Austria (the assassination of Austro-fascist dictator Engelbert Dollfuss). The Nazis were international pariahs thanks to their blatant racism (especially after Kristallnacht) but that didn't stop Western corporations like Ford, Chase, and Coca-Cola from doing business there anyway. Fascism was wildly popular across Europe between 1920 and 1945, and many countries were ruled by fascist (or fascist-like, such as Falangist Spain or Portugal's Novo Estado) regimes during that time, as the bourgeoise came to fear socialism's popularity and equated it with the excesses of Stalin to increase general distrust of it. It was only when Germany attacked one country too many that the war started (even though it had already been raging in China for almost a decade...) and anti-fascist propaganda really started appearing in the West.

replies.text:
@radschele1815 The German Republic was their first attempt at a democracy. They were just a German Empire, ie a monarchy. Kaiser is an emperor title. The monarchy had just abdicated. Germany was severely hurting economically. The war did not go well for them. You had the failed Communist revolution, defeated by the Freicorps to which the NSDAP came out of. You had these factions in armed conflict in the streets. The NSDAP was one of two far right parties during the Weimar days. 

The NSDAP did not gain power overnight. Once in power, yes. Hitler abolished the KPD and they lost something like 83 seats in the German Parliament. This gave the Right their majority. The KPD was the Communist party.

replies.author: @Nocturnalux
replies.text:
Even in Japan it was not overnight, the already fragile Meiji-style parliamentary system was undermined by militarists until it crumbled from within and only its shell remained.

My own country, Portugal, embarked on a decades long Fascist nightmare that lasted long after WWII. It did so gradually, so much that Salazar, the dictator who took hold, started out as a reluctant finance minister who, at one point, was elected. There was a lot of chaos as the Republic, while full of good ideas, had been compromised by rightists, especially the Church. WWI was a disaster for the country, tanking the already never healthy economy and the influenza outbreak made things even worse.

In the final days of the Republic, cabinets followed cabinets, we would have several in a year. So there was no functioning democracy and democracy, as such, came to be seen as ineffectual.

By the time democracy finally died, people were relieved.

"The Haavara (Transfer) Agreement, negotiated by Eliezer Hoofein, director of the Anglo-Palestine Bank,[16] was agreed to by the Reich Economics Ministry in 1933, and continued, with declining German government support,[17] until it was wound up in 1939.[18] Under the agreement, Jews emigrating from Germany could use their assets to purchase German-manufactured goods for export, thus salvaging their personal assets during emigration. The agreement provided a substantial export market for German factories in British-ruled Palestine."

"The Haavara Agreement was thought among some German circles to be a possible way to solve the "Jewish problem." The head of the Middle Eastern division of the foreign ministry, the anti-NSDAP politician Werner Otto von Hentig, supported the policy of settling Jews in Palestine. Hentig believed that if the Jewish population was concentrated in a single foreign entity, then foreign diplomatic policy and containment of the Jews would become easier.[21] Hitler's own support of the Haavara Agreement was unclear and varied throughout the 1930s. Initially, Hitler seemed indifferent to the economic details of the plan, but he supported it in the period from September 1937 to 1939.[22]

After the German invasion of Poland in September 1939 the program was ended.[18]"

replies.author: @spacecase8888
replies.text:
@SupremeEmperorKizza Do you know what the Federalist Papers are? They are the documents the Constitution was based on. In the Federalist Papers, James Madison defined a "Republic" as a "Representative Democracy". This is the definition of Republic used in the Constitution. So you can see how saying "We're a Republic not a Democracy" is completely nonsensical. 

I don't know what you think a Republic is, but in the broad sense of the term, it's just a system of government with no monarch. In other words, the sovereignty of the state is not derived from the monarch, but from the people as a whole. The only reason why any of our representatives have power is because they have been voted in by the people. That's Representative Democracy. That's what the US Republic is. If we can keep it that way. It's under assault by people like yourself.

replies.author: @martinbruhn5274
replies.text: It's especially weird, that the supreme court holds so much influence, that everybody knows the names of the supreme justices and everything about them. I don't know anybody in the german constitutional court by name, or anything about them. Generally speaking, they have a more passive role, with their main focus being on reviewing the constitutionality of laws being passed and giving their statements and possible adjustments to fix potentially risque laws. They're also not in their position for life. I think they serve 12 year terms, they have (I think) a maximum of 2 terms and an age limit, they must not exceed. Also, our chancellor doesn't get to choose the judges, but (I think) that gets sort of rotated between our parliament and the representative body of our states (they are chosen by state parliaments and not elected). But the corresponding other branch of the legislative also has to agree (or something like that, I'm not entirely sure tbh and I thin I would have to look up all the details)

replies.author: @ItWasSaucerShaped
replies.text:
Hypothetically, the intent was to take partisan bias out of the courts by allowing them to not be beholden to electoral politics. If their life and career is lived outside of the election cycle, in theory, they can strictly focus their opinions on the law and jurisprudence. 

Of course that hasn't worked out at all and if anything has resulted in the opposite of the intended effect, but I can see why someone would intuitively think that this would be a good way to get a non-partisan court.

author: @PaperMario64
text: I always enjoy your videos. I‚Äôm a Black American female. One of my many concerns is that some of our white brethren tend to ignore issues that only affect us. They seem to perform elaborate mental gymnastics to explain away any issue as self-inflicted or a personal failure and so the fight or solution does not involve them. Even issues that will clearly reach them eventually are kinda ignored and not discussed for fear of feeling uncomfortable. My wish is that they would see the bigger picture of how an injustice to us is like a canary in a coal mine. You stamp it out before it gets bigger. Some examples of this include the opioid crisis, teen pregnancy and police brutality. But this also applies to Gerrymandering, which will eventually reach areas of consequence if bad people are allowed to continue unchecked.

Now I can‚Äôt remember it all, but basically he went on about how if we are serious about wanting to solve the issue of inequality we, (white guys), should be more eager to focus on the inequality some minority groups face, rather than focus on how our own compare.

Having had many a debate on social media with white American guys, it really troubles me seeing how even some who do recognize that there‚Äôs a huge inequality problem in the US, and that there are issues that harms certain groups more than others, they still has the position that unless it‚Äôs possible to burn down the system and start in a way that will also benefit them personally, it‚Äôs not worth pursuing- and sometimes even blaming the minority groups for not setting their grievances aside and join them in either voting 3rd party or abstain from voting , (and thereby handing over the election to someone who will make life a lot harder on these minority groups), to "teach the politicians a lesson"!

I honestly don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs coincidental that it‚Äôs almost always a white guy I end up debating on such issues - and it‚Äôs probably no coincidence either that it has often been someone who was a fanboi of someone like Dimmy Dork!

I find it hard to believe that white America isn't discussing this stuff for fear of feeling uncomfortable when walking into Target or similar stores, companies managed largely by whites, you can find plenty of children's books about anti-racism and pride, and all national 24-hour news networks besides the two expressly rightwing ones routinely cover gerrymandering and voter suppression and how both specifically target blacks and other nonwhites, and it's not uncommon for upper-middle class elite whites to engage in anti-racist book clubs where they talk about white fragility as if in a confessional.

If you're talking about red America? Then absolutely, red America does not want to talk about it. But I presume that the usual Weimar comparison is to point the finger at "centrists" and "moderates" who are supposedly guaranteed by some sort of political game theory or class-interest prophecy to side with red America when the weather isn't fair. And, no, for all of the problems of center-left blue American whites, having "uncomfortable" conversations about race is not something they're hesitant to do.

The hard-left has a stronger distaste for identity politics than the center-left does. Self-avowed socialists and anti-imperialists like Glenn Greenwald and Tulsi Gabbard and those girls from the Red Scare podcast are doing more to defend the proto-fascist right than center-leftists are. Whether or not horseshoe theory is true in the long-term, in the short-term horseshoe theory has been scoring a lot of points lately.

There's nothing wrong with pointing out that America is still racist, just be honest about who actually is denying that and don't act like it's a difficult conversation for centrist whites when CNN and MSNBC, hardly radical institutions, are talking about them all the time.

replies.author: @keith7261
replies.text: @EricLeafericson not only obsessed with trying to understand, I think a lot of them also want to be able to pride themselves on being a ‚Äúwhite savior‚Äù and want to take the lead in these movements. I think it‚Äôs important that privileged people are supportive in movements, rather than demand a leadership role amongst a marginalized group. Rather than do individualism, we should be advocating collectively for a society that betters everyone, because we can‚Äôt possibly change the minds of those who willingly discriminate others quickly, that can only be achieved over time by bridging the gap between groups. And it‚Äôs not that white people necessarily have it easy in America, it‚Äôs just easier than it is for other races. Under our country‚Äôs structure, we all feel economic burdens; medical debt, inability to afford education, having to work most of the day just to be able to feed a family. It‚Äôs important that everyone can come together and demand change to better the lives of the middle and lower class. replies.author: @diskopartizan0850
replies.text:
The Troubles killed more than 3000 people and injured 50,000. That was after a war of independence and a civil war that killed around 4000 combined. Given the size of Ireland and Northern Ireland's population currently ~1,500,000, these aren't insignificant numbers. 

For most of the Troubles the British Army didn't travel by road in South Armagh, it was too dangerous. Conditions meant that at times 3000 soldiers were deployed to an area with a population of 23,000. 123 British soldiers were killed in South Armagh during the Troubles.

Current clashes between left and right in the US aren't really comparable. I don't think conditions would support a Troubles-style event in the US. If they did, you're talking about millions of casualties, thousands of military deaths, major deployments of soldiers, and disruption to daily life for huge parts of the country.

author: @sashaneumann
text:
Everyone (including me) likes the flashy bits of history, the speeches, the riots, the revolutions etc., but we often forget how important the underlying processes are. By the time the flashy bits happen, a million quiet boring things happened that lead to that moment. I experience this in my own country as well. I'm from Russia, and things like taking over the Crimea and the invasion of Ukraine were all huge moments, but there was a million small things happening before that. A great analogy I heard was the frog in the bucket - in order to cook a frog you don't need to blast them with boiling water right away, you just slowly raise the temperature, and the frog won't notice until it's dead. We had a government formed after a messy crash of a dictatorship, and even though most people in power were not that democratically inclined, there was still hope in politics, there was real opposition, but it slowly but surely got crushed. If you look at Russia 15 years ago and now it's a huge difference, now any opposing political thought gets destroyed by police searches, jail time for likes on a post, massive fines that destroy people's lives, and all it took was 15-20 years of quietly passing laws, appointing judges, faking election results and boom - now if someone gets prison time for holding up a piece of paper that says 'no to war' it's perfectly legal within our system.
TLDR: Shit sucks, man. –°–ª–∞–≤–∞ –£–∫—Ä–∞—ó–Ω—ñ!

replies.author: @adrianthoroughgood1191
replies.text: Have people actually gone to prison for protesting? I know people have been arrested but have any been imprisoned? That journalist on the main TV news only got a fine and no prison. I know in theory the law allows for up to 10 years but what actually happens is often different.

replies.author: @sashaneumann
replies.text: @adrianthoroughgood1191 A lot of people get short sentences like 15-30 days in prison, but in some cases it's much longer, Alexey Gorinov got 7 years, for example. Daniil Tikhomirov - 1,5 years. Also, some people get dragged through the court system without an actual sentence, like Alexandra Skochilenko, who's been in jail since April and doesn't have a sentence yet, the court dates get delayed all the time. I think it's purposeful torture in her case. bc she has serious health problems which got a lot worse since she's been jailed and she's being refused medical attention. A lot of people who got shorter sentences lost their jobs and with them the last means to live and close attention from the police and Centre E (Centre against extremism, basically a system of internal political spies and snitches). If you get caught protesting the second time, the punishment will be more severe.

replies.author: @adrianthoroughgood1191
replies.text: Willy_Tepes that's not true. No one is getting prison just for protesting in the UK. The JSO people where planning direct action that would cause big disruption to infrastructure. The people getting prison now are for violent riots not protests. They are typically getting 2 years or so. The penalty for murder is life. You can get out on probation in some cases but you are never free.

According to Pew research, around 65% of US adults support anti discrimination protections for transgender people, but only 38% believe that gender can be different from sex assigned at birth, a number that is shrinking in recent years. This number is split between age demographics, with around half of those under 30 and only a third of those over 50 agreeing.

Essentially, most either support or don't have an opinion on anti discrimination policies, but most don't accept trans people as the gender they identify as.

@Axel-iy4xs I think that's short sighted. Think about the people who believe Trans people should be protected by anti-discrimination laws, but aren't valid (nearly half of people who support anti-discrimination laws protecting Trans people) - what goes through such a person's mind? What do they really think about Trans people? I'm not going to print hate speech in the youtube comments section, but if you can't bring yourself to say "Trans people *are* the gender they identify as," you implicitly must believe one of the hateful lines about why they *aren't* actually that gender.

That is not a recipe for a stable and inclusive Republic that actually protects Trans people.

That's why now we're seeing Libs saying things like "we need to stop focusing on 'niche issues' " (Sorry, Trans rights are just too niche to be worth defending! -Hillary Clinton), and Dave Chappelle being offered an Emmy for an unfunny special that was really just thinly veiled hate speech papered over with some of the weakest material of his career (Hollywood, who is giving him the accolade, usually being considered the bastion of effete performative liberals, according to the right wing). And Trans people being targeted effectively with a reworked blood libel ("they're grooming children!") is being met with toothless condemnations - very little real action is being taken by any legislature.

Overall, I am deeply alarmed by the pace of the backsliding going on in the country, even moreso that there are people who want to be allies who seem to think it's not a big deal.

replies.author: @daylanhammer4551
replies.text: All these non-skeptical, aggressive, and dogmatic thinkers in the replies. It's laughable. I'm not intimidated by you in the least. Now here let me begin dismantling your points. First, many of these procedures including surgeries and puberty blockers are most certainly irreversible. If you'd like an entire book on the subject read Abigail Shrier's "Irreversible Damage". Now I know you folks like to dismiss anyone who disagrees with you as a fascist, bigot, terf, etc, but that's not how rational argument works. If you'd like to refute the book: attack the evidence presented, not the character of the author. Science doesn't cease being true because a given fact makes you feel uncomfortable, it ceases being true when you actually refute the evidence. If you want to give a chapter by chapter critique of the book that's fine but the youtube comment section isn't a place for that. The irreversible damage by these practices has been well documented. My point stands. Additionally, even if you think I'm wrong about this particular issue, it doesn't mean I'm right wing or a fascist. There's nothing about rejecting gender psuedoscience that means you can't support universal healthcare, ending the drug war, anti-interventionist foreign policy, gay marriage, or the myriad of other left wing positions. We have to move past this "if you don't agree with me on 100% of issues you're my enemy" attitude. This is why the left loses so often, we get fractured over minute differences and lose sight of the bigger picture. And last thing I want to say is: many of the activists on this issue have made a tactical error. They're taken the trans movement which is a mental health crisis, and framed it as a civil rights issue. Now because they've done this, any attempt to actually help these folk is being viewed as bigotry and getting people reflexively angry on the internet for no reason. Cool down. In a few decades we'll look back on this era like the medical practice of lobotomies. You're not the next MLK. Give it a break.

@anjetto1 They point of the comparison was to say that there are levels to this. My whole point is that, unlike you, I am not a super hero.  I cannot fell an international empire (the scorpion) all by my lonesome.

But, if I can convince ten people to pick up a hammer, and they convince ten, and those 100 convince another ten, then maybe we'd have enough hammers to actually smash that scorpion that you are talking about.

Even the people who don't pick up a hammer might be deradicalized enough to not continue to defend the scorpion.  

And no, no judges or cops or law enforcement, at least I don't think.  But I do have the ear of teachers, deans, scientists, and a whole lot of people who are parents, siblings, children, etc.

I'm sure that's small potatoes to you, but less trauma and less suicide in the world means a lot to me.  It means a lot to me when someone that I haven't seen in forever tells me that my writing has helped them find some peace.  

And seeing that other people are trying to do the same, in many ways big and small, is what convinces me to continue to try, and sometimes go bolder and bigger.  

Many of us are not superheroes like you, and by shitting on what we are able to do, you're essentially telling us that we shouldn't even try.  

So, like, what are you even trying to accomplish here? üòÇ

author: @BberryBberry
text:
I love the point about how the beer hall putsch wasn't what started fascism since, at least as best as I can remember from my underfunded American public high school education, that's kinda how we learned it in school. Out of no where, Mr. Scary Man came in and used his magic evil powers to start WWII. Ok obviously that's a bit of an exaggeration, but truthfully the beer hall putsch and Reichstag fire were all we were taught in our history classes before starting the chapter on WWII. And I think that lends itself to a particularly strange way we talk about politics in general, at least here in contemporary America. That being the constant tendency to lean heavily into magical thinking.

I think that's why Jan 6 captured people's attention more than the constant stream of supreme court travesties rolling out for the last decade. The US Constitution is another great example where magical thinking is at play. I often jokely call the constitution "the third testament" since so many people treat the document like they're in some Christian Evangelical bible study and not basic legal studies. It's absolute insanity. I think it's partially to blame for how misinformation has become so rampant. The truth doesn't matter, only your "beliefs" matter in the "market place of free speech." It's a sort of mindset I find to be incredibly dangerous; it's how the republicans justify rolling back human rights and how the democrats sit on their hands while telling themselves that American institutions will magically save them

author: @sammosaurusrex
text:
When we needed him most, the King returned

For real though, I've been loving (if that's the right word? It can be kind of a distressing listen) The Iron Dice. In the US, basically all we're taught about the Weimar period is "The treaty of Versaille was unfair -> hyperinflation -> aggrieved Germans vote for Hitler," which not only leaves out a lot of details, it's a very misleading narrative that is flat out wrong in my opinion, but widely believed in the US because of gaps in our education system. I don't think I was even taught about the revolutionary toppling of the monarchy in school, all the focus was on Wilson's 14 points and the decisions of other victorious powers.

Learning more about the period has been really eye opening.

Edit: Also, sorry for referring to you in monarchist terms in the comments on a podcast about Democracy, lol

replies.author: @Alex-nr6cv
replies.text:
interestingly i find people dont realise fearmongering of the TOV was done deliberetly by the legacy media establishment to sow dissent in weimar, so TOV being a major cause is acc quite heavily disputed, the treatise were harsh yes, but it was significantly less extreme than the treaty of Brest-Litovsk, which saw the nascent soviet union lose a significant area of territory to germany.

 they renounced finland (whos independence at this time was recognised) as well as several more western territories that fit in the agricultural area the facists of the day used to espouse ideas of a "greater germany" - facism while formalised by mussolinni, should not be put into a neat tidy timeline of beggining with him, mussolinni merely capitalised on popular iconography, and thats key, facism can be used to describe the catalysts that lead to its creation, this includes ideas that become integral to that particular facsist states desired status qou - (see that here in the fight for trans rights worldwide). 

so really the TOV  being harsh was part of the punishment of that german imperialist legacy, early weimar was hardly squeaky clean with how particularly it cosied up with facists to crush communism (btw i think this centrism leading to facism as a societal pitfall being a thing comes from mussolinis predecesor giovanni giolitti, who established appeasing far right ideology to be tolerated) 


hope this potentially elaborated on information you already new, i dont know if it makes much sense, i wrote it stoned

replies.author: @sammosaurusrex
replies.text:
@Alex-nr6cv "Write stoned, edit sober" -Ernest Hemingweed

But yeah, I hear you. I'm not at all familiar with the terms of the USSR's exit from WWI, but that is a fascinating comparison, since they two parallel endings to the same war that both began with a revolution but had radically different outcomes.

replies.text:
Guilty of the 818 
The Naz1 movement called themselves "socialist" just to get people in the door. 
They were explicitly reactionary. They were set against the strong, popular socialist, communist, and labor union movements.
In fact, the Naz1s were funded by the rich business moguls specifically to suppress the socialists.
The Naz1s threw the communists, socialists and union leaders into concentration camps BEFORE they got started on the Jewish people.
...Happy?
I believe Dan Arrows _already covered this_ much better about 2 years ago, take a look at his videos.

replies.author: @grmpEqweer
replies.text:
Guilty of the 818 
They weren't with the workers. They went after the trade unionists.
Socialism isn't just a label, it's an idea that the workers should own the means of production.
Not "The god-emperor should own everything." 
I get really tired of having this same stupid argument, you know.
You've read about "the night of long knives"?
If not, please go read about how Hitler offed the left wing of his own party.

replies.author: @grmpEqweer
replies.text:
Guilty of the 818 
Fascism is palingenetic hypernationalism, but quite frankly I usually look at Umberto Eco's 14 characteristics.
They're really useful.

Socialism is when the workers own and control the means of production. And I'm a socialist.

Now, as to why you have been fed the point of view you were fed...
Pundits on the right in America erroneously characterize fascism as a left-wing movement, and they do this purposefully.  

It's in part to deny the authoritarianism of their own movement.

They want the firm association to be made of left wing = authoritarian. 
And right wing = freedom.

(Which, considering I used to be an anarchist and I'm still sympathetic to that point of view...no. there's PLENTY of anti-authoritarians on the left.)

It's an erroneous viewpoint, being put forth for an ideological reason, by people who want you to think socialist = authoritarian and maybe = Naz1. 
So the argument really annoys me, as you may have noticed.
I'll brb, see if I can dig you up a text article.

replies.author: @dynamicworlds1
replies.text:
@slashismyhommie8182 I don't disagree, but I'm glad they exist.  I remember Gamergate.  Having people who can appeal to edgy gamer bros and bring them left rather than leaving them to be swept up by fascist propaganda is part of diversity of tactics.

We all have some approaches some leftists use that make us cringe inside, but as long as they are being a net positive, we all have bigger things to worry about than other leftists who rub us the wrong way or even get some stuff wrong now and then.

I'm not big on religion either, but since there are people who are going to be more effectively moved over by biblical arguments, I'm glad that not all preachers are right-wing.  I prefer secular leftism, and have good reasons to do so, but I recognize I don't have the luxury of overly gatekeeping.

As long as someone's not trying to position themselves to stab me in the back at the first opportunity, we can push our disagreements off for later or at least agree to disagree for the time being, and it's also fine if they don't really get along with each other and prefer to avoid each other.

Not for me‚â†bad leftism
And even people I think cause more problems than the help sometimes do work I can respect and acknowledge as good.

(I hope none of that came across as trying to imply anything about you, btw.  I'm just adding my personal general perspective in a way I hope is coming across as non-accusatory.)

I watched Babylon Berlin and read some Erich K√§stner recently and just can't shake of the feeling that some of the things that are happening now that seem to be just a bit too similar to what has happened before. It really freaks me out seeing the incompetence of the liberal opposition, the wide-spread belief that it can't happen because whatever, the impotence of the left (or whatever is left of it after Thatcher/Reagan era). Guilty of the 818 socialism is a model of decentralized government, essentially. That's not to say there should be NO government... just that there be no avenue for a complete ruling "class" to emerge and inevitably exploit or make second-class citizens out of the people at large (who are necessary for ANY kind of society to rise).

It's simple. _No person nor entity_ should have unilateral power over people's living conditions, least of all, to intentionally "triage" entire communities for their own personal benefit.

As things stand under capitalism, that's _exactly_ what happens every day.
